classification_procedure.definition:
Any of various rocky or gaseous bodies that revolve in approximately elliptical orbits 
around the sun and are visible by its reflected light; esp. each of the planets Mercury, Venus, 
Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune, and (until 2006) Pluto (in order of increasing 
distance from the sun); a similar body revolving around another star. Also: any of various 
smaller bodies that revolve around these (cf. satellite n. 2a).

results.name: 94 Ceti b
results.description: 94 Ceti b or 94 Ceti Ab to distinguish it from the distant red dwarf companion, is an extrasolar planet orbiting its  star once every 1.2 years.  It was discovered on August 7, 2000 by a team led by Michel Mayor.It is most stable if its inclination is about 65 or 115, yielding a mass of about 1.85 that of Jupiter.
results.rationale: 94 Ceti b fits the definition of a planet as it is a body that revolves around a star, in this case, its own star. The definition does not specify that the star has to be the sun, therefore, 94 Ceti b can still be classified as a planet even though it revolves around a different star. Furthermore, the definition includes bodies that are similar to those that revolve around the sun, and 94 Ceti b, with a mass of about 1.85 that of Jupiter, is similar to one of the planets in our solar system. Therefore, based on the provided definition, 94 Ceti b can be classified as a planet.

results.name: Kepler-40b
results.description: Kepler-40b, formerly known as KOI-428b, is a hot Jupiter discovered in orbit around the star Kepler-40, which is about to become a red giant. The planet was first noted as a transit event by NASA's Kepler spacecraft. The Kepler team made data collected by its satellite publicly available, including data on Kepler-40; French and Swiss astronomers used the equivalent to one night of measurements on the SOPHIE échelle spectrograph to collect all the data needed to show that a planet was producing the periodic dimming of Kepler-40. The planet, Kepler-40b, is twice the mass of Jupiter and slightly larger than it in size, making it as dense as Neptune. The planet is also nearly thirteen times hotter than Jupiter and orbits five times closer to its star than Mercury is from the Sun.
results.rationale: Kepler-40b fits the definition of a planet as it is a body that revolves in an orbit around a star, in this case, the star Kepler-40. This is evidenced by the fact that it was discovered due to its transit event, which is when a planet moves across the face of its star, causing a periodic dimming of the star's light. Furthermore, Kepler-40b is described as being larger and denser than Jupiter, indicating that it is a substantial body, not a smaller entity like a satellite. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Kepler-40b can be classified as a planet.

results.name: HD 34445 g
results.description: HD 34445 is a star with multiple exoplanetary companions in the equatorial constellation of Orion. With an apparent visual magnitude of 7.31, it is a 7th magnitude star that is too dim to be readily visible to the naked eye. The system is located at a distance of 150.5 light years from the Sun based on parallax measurements, but is drifting closer with a high radial velocity of −79 km/s. It is expected to draw as close as 57.5 light-years in ~492,000 years.This is an ordinary G-type main-sequence star with a stellar classification of G0 V, which means it is a Sun-like star that is generating energy through core hydrogen fusion. It is considered a metal-rich star, showing a much higher metallicity compared to the Sun. Despite this it is an older star and chromospherically quiet, lying about 0.8 magnitudes above the main sequence. This star is larger, hotter, brighter, and more massive than the Sun. It is spinning with a projected rotational velocity of ~3 km/s, giving it a rotation period of around 22 days.
results.rationale: The definition of a planet includes any body that revolves in an approximately elliptical orbit around a star and is visible by its reflected light. The description of HD 34445 g indicates that it is an exoplanetary companion to the star HD 34445, which means it revolves around this star. Therefore, based on the provided definition, HD 34445 g can be classified as a planet.

results.name: Kepler-1647b
results.description:
Kepler-1647b (sometimes named Kepler-1647(AB)-b to distinguish it from the secondary component)  is a circumbinary exoplanet that orbits the binary star system Kepler-1647, 3,700 light-years (1,100 pc) from Earth in the constellation Cygnus. It was announced on June 13, 2016, in San Diego at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society. It was detected using the transit method, when it caused the dimming of the primary star, and then again of the secondary star blended with the primary star eclipse.
The first transit of the planet was identified in 2012, but at the time the single event was not enough to rule out contamination, or confirm it as a planet. It was discovered by the analysis of the Kepler light-curve, which showed the planet in transit.
results.rationale: Kepler-1647b fits the definition of a planet as it is a body that revolves around a star system, in this case, the binary star system Kepler-1647. This is similar to how the planets in our solar system revolve around the sun. Furthermore, it was detected using the transit method, which involves observing the dimming of a star as a planet passes in front of it, further supporting the assertion that Kepler-1647b is a planet. Additionally, the definition includes bodies that revolve around other stars, not just our sun, which would include exoplanets like Kepler-1647b.

results.name: Nu2 Lupi b
results.description: Nu2 Lupi (ν2 Lupi) is a 6th magnitude G-type main-sequence star located approximately 48 light-years away in the constellation of Lupus. The physical properties of the star are similar to those of the Sun, though Nu2 Lupi is significantly older.
results.rationale: The definition of a planet states that it is a body that revolves in approximately elliptical orbits around the sun or a similar body revolving around another star. While the description of Nu2 Lupi b does not explicitly state that it revolves around a star, it is implied by the fact that it is located in the constellation of Lupus and is associated with a G-type main-sequence star. Therefore, based on the provided definition, it can be argued that Nu2 Lupi b is a planet. However, more specific information about Nu2 Lupi b's characteristics and its orbit would be needed to confirm this assertion.

results.name: C/1957 P1 (Mrkos)
results.description: Comet Mrkos, formally known as C/1957 P1 (old style 1957d), was a non-periodic comet discovered in 1957 by Antonín Mrkos. It was one of  two bright comets that had their perihelion in 1957, the other being Comet Arend–Roland. Its peak magnitude was estimated to be around 1 and it has been characterised as a great comet.
results.rationale: The assertion that C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) is a planet cannot be supported by the given definition and information. According to the definition, a planet is a rocky or gaseous body that revolves in approximately elliptical orbits around the sun and is visible by its reflected light. However, the description of C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) identifies it as a non-periodic comet, not a planet. Comets are composed of ice, dust, and rocky material, not just rock or gas, and they have highly elliptical orbits that bring them close to the sun and then back to the outer solar system, unlike the more stable, approximately elliptical orbits of planets. Therefore, based on the provided definition and information, C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) cannot be classified as a planet.

results.name: 5015 Litke
results.description:
The following is a partial list of minor planets, running from minor-planet number 5001 through 6000, inclusive. The primary data for this and other partial lists is based on JPL's \"Small-Body Orbital Elements\" and \"Data Available from the Minor Planet Center\". A detailed description of the table's columns and additional sources are given on the main page including a complete list of every page in this series, and a statistical break-up on the dynamical classification of minor planets.
Also see the summary list of all named bodies in numerical and alphabetical order, and the corresponding naming citations for the number range of this particular list. New namings may only be added to this list after official publication, as the preannouncement of names is condemned by the Working Group for Small Bodies Nomenclature of the International Astronomical Union.
results.rationale: The definition of a planet includes any of various smaller bodies that revolve around larger bodies such as the sun. The description of 5015 Litke identifies it as a minor planet, which implies that it is a smaller body that revolves around a larger body. Therefore, based on the provided definition, one could argue that 5015 Litke is a planet.

results.name: 6P/d'Arrest
results.description:
6P/d'Arrest (also known as d'Arrest's Comet or Comet d'Arrest) is a periodic Jupiter-family comet in the Solar System, orbiting between Mars and Jupiter. It passed 0.15124 AU (22,625,000 km; 14,059,000 mi) from the Earth on August 12, 1976. The most recent perihelion passage took place on September 17, 2021, when the comet had a solar elongation of 95 degrees at approximately apparent magnitude of 10.The comet last came to perihelion (closest approach to the Sun) on March 2, 2015, but it was in an unfavorable apparition as it had a solar elongation of less than 30 degrees from October 2014 until May 2015.In 1991, Andrea Carusi and Giovanni B. Valsecchi (Istituto Astrofisica Spaziale, Rome), and Ľubor Kresák and Margita Kresáková (Slovak Astronomical Institute, Bratislava) independently suggested this comet was the same as a comet observed by Philippe de La Hire in 1678.It was first observed by Heinrich Ludwig d'Arrest, in Leipzig, Germany, on 28th and 30 June 1851.The comet nucleus is estimated at about 3.2 km in diameter.6P/d was one of a trio of comets targeted by the ill-fated CONTOUR mission, an unmanned discovery program mission, that was launched but contact was lost soon after reaching orbit.
If it had been functional, the planned date for CONTOUR's study of d'Arrest would have been 2008, after visiting two other comets.Around 2007, 6P/d was one of nine comets examined for a comet sample return mission study. In the 2010s a comet surface sample return mission was selected as the New Frontiers Program finalist, but the recently studied comet 67P was chosen as the selected target.
results.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it would be challenging to argue that 6P/d'Arrest is a planet. The definition of a planet states that it is a rocky or gaseous body that revolves in approximately elliptical orbits around the sun and is visible by its reflected light. While 6P/d'Arrest does revolve around the sun, it is identified as a comet, not a planet. Comets and planets are distinct categories of celestial bodies. Comets, like 6P/d'Arrest, are composed of ice, dust, and rocky material, unlike planets which are primarily rocky or gaseous. Furthermore, the visibility of comets is often due to their coma (a cloud of gas and dust that forms around the comet) and tail, not reflected light as is the case with planets. Therefore, based on the provided definition and information, it would not be accurate to classify 6P/d'Arrest as a planet.

results.name: 893 Leopoldina
results.description: 893 Leopoldina (prov. designation: A918 KD or 1918 DS) is a large and elongated background asteroid from the outer regions of the asteroid belt. It was discovered by German astronomer Max Wolf at the Heidelberg Observatory on 31 May 1918. The dark carbonaceous C-type asteroid has a rotation period of 14.1 hours and measures approximately 76 kilometers (47 miles) in diameter. It was named for Germany's national academy, the Academy of Sciences Leopoldina in Halle.
results.rationale: The definition of a planet includes "any of various smaller bodies that revolve around these (cf. satellite n. 2a)." The description of 893 Leopoldina states that it is a "background asteroid from the outer regions of the asteroid belt" that revolves around the sun. Therefore, based on the provided definition, one could argue that 893 Leopoldina is a planet. However, it's important to note that this argument is based on a broad interpretation of the definition, and in common astronomical terms, asteroids are not typically classified as planets.

classification_procedure.definition:
A planet is a celestial body that (a) has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to 
overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, 
and (b) is in orbit around a star, and is neither a star nor a satellite of a planet.

results.name: 94 Ceti b
results.description: 94 Ceti b or 94 Ceti Ab to distinguish it from the distant red dwarf companion, is an extrasolar planet orbiting its  star once every 1.2 years.  It was discovered on August 7, 2000 by a team led by Michel Mayor.It is most stable if its inclination is about 65 or 115, yielding a mass of about 1.85 that of Jupiter.
results.rationale: 94 Ceti b fits the definition of a planet because it is a celestial body that is in orbit around a star, specifically its star 94 Ceti. The description does not explicitly state that 94 Ceti b has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, but it does mention that its mass is about 1.85 that of Jupiter, which is a known planet. Therefore, it can be inferred that 94 Ceti b also has sufficient mass to meet this criterion. Finally, the description does not identify 94 Ceti b as a star or a satellite of a planet, which means it meets the final criterion in the definition of a planet. Therefore, based on the provided definition and the information in the description, it can be argued that 94 Ceti b is a planet.

results.name: Kepler-40b
results.description: Kepler-40b, formerly known as KOI-428b, is a hot Jupiter discovered in orbit around the star Kepler-40, which is about to become a red giant. The planet was first noted as a transit event by NASA's Kepler spacecraft. The Kepler team made data collected by its satellite publicly available, including data on Kepler-40; French and Swiss astronomers used the equivalent to one night of measurements on the SOPHIE échelle spectrograph to collect all the data needed to show that a planet was producing the periodic dimming of Kepler-40. The planet, Kepler-40b, is twice the mass of Jupiter and slightly larger than it in size, making it as dense as Neptune. The planet is also nearly thirteen times hotter than Jupiter and orbits five times closer to its star than Mercury is from the Sun.
results.rationale: Kepler-40b fits the definition of a planet as it is a celestial body that has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces, which is evident from its round shape and its size, which is slightly larger than Jupiter. This indicates that it has assumed a hydrostatic equilibrium shape. Additionally, Kepler-40b is in orbit around a star, specifically Kepler-40, which is about to become a red giant. This satisfies the second part of the definition that a planet must be in orbit around a star. Finally, it is neither a star itself nor a satellite of a planet, as it is described as a hot Jupiter, a type of planet, and there is no mention of it being a satellite of another planet. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Kepler-40b can be classified as a planet.

results.name: HD 34445 g
results.description: HD 34445 is a star with multiple exoplanetary companions in the equatorial constellation of Orion. With an apparent visual magnitude of 7.31, it is a 7th magnitude star that is too dim to be readily visible to the naked eye. The system is located at a distance of 150.5 light years from the Sun based on parallax measurements, but is drifting closer with a high radial velocity of −79 km/s. It is expected to draw as close as 57.5 light-years in ~492,000 years.This is an ordinary G-type main-sequence star with a stellar classification of G0 V, which means it is a Sun-like star that is generating energy through core hydrogen fusion. It is considered a metal-rich star, showing a much higher metallicity compared to the Sun. Despite this it is an older star and chromospherically quiet, lying about 0.8 magnitudes above the main sequence. This star is larger, hotter, brighter, and more massive than the Sun. It is spinning with a projected rotational velocity of ~3 km/s, giving it a rotation period of around 22 days.
results.rationale: The text does not provide sufficient information to assert that HD 34445 g is a planet. The description only provides information about the star HD 34445, not about any specific celestial body orbiting it. To classify HD 34445 g as a planet, we would need information confirming that it is a celestial body in orbit around the star HD 34445, that it has sufficient mass to assume a nearly round shape due to its self-gravity, and that it is not a star itself or a satellite of another planet.

results.name: Kepler-1647b
results.description:
Kepler-1647b (sometimes named Kepler-1647(AB)-b to distinguish it from the secondary component)  is a circumbinary exoplanet that orbits the binary star system Kepler-1647, 3,700 light-years (1,100 pc) from Earth in the constellation Cygnus. It was announced on June 13, 2016, in San Diego at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society. It was detected using the transit method, when it caused the dimming of the primary star, and then again of the secondary star blended with the primary star eclipse.
The first transit of the planet was identified in 2012, but at the time the single event was not enough to rule out contamination, or confirm it as a planet. It was discovered by the analysis of the Kepler light-curve, which showed the planet in transit.
results.rationale: Kepler-1647b fits the definition of a planet as it is a celestial body that is in orbit around a star system, in this case, the binary star system Kepler-1647. The description does not explicitly state that Kepler-1647b has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, but it can be inferred from the fact that it was detected using the transit method. This method involves observing the dimming of a star as a planet passes in front of it, which would only be possible if the planet is round. Furthermore, Kepler-1647b is neither a star nor a satellite of a planet, which aligns with the remaining part of the definition. Therefore, based on the provided definition and the information given, Kepler-1647b can be classified as a planet.

results.rationale: The provided description does not provide enough information to definitively assert that Nu2 Lupi b is a planet. classification_procedure.definition:
A planet [1] is a celestial body that (a) is in orbit around the Sun, (b) has sufficient 
mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic 
equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and (c) has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit.

results.name: 94 Ceti b
results.description: 94 Ceti b or 94 Ceti Ab to distinguish it from the distant red dwarf companion, is an extrasolar planet orbiting its  star once every 1.2 years.  It was discovered on August 7, 2000 by a team led by Michel Mayor.It is most stable if its inclination is about 65 or 115, yielding a mass of about 1.85 that of Jupiter.
results.rationale: 94 Ceti b can be considered a planet based on the provided definition. Firstly, it is stated that 94 Ceti b is an extrasolar planet orbiting its star, which aligns with the first criterion of the definition that a planet is a celestial body in orbit around the Sun (or in this case, its own star). Secondly, the fact that it has a mass of about 1.85 that of Jupiter suggests that it has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces and assume a hydrostatic equilibrium shape, meeting the second criterion. Lastly, while the description does not explicitly state that 94 Ceti b has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit, the fact that it is referred to as a planet implies that it meets this criterion as well. Therefore, based on the provided definition and the information given, it can be argued that 94 Ceti b is a planet.

results.name: Kepler-40b
results.description: Kepler-40b, formerly known as KOI-428b, is a hot Jupiter discovered in orbit around the star Kepler-40, which is about to become a red giant. The planet was first noted as a transit event by NASA's Kepler spacecraft. The Kepler team made data collected by its satellite publicly available, including data on Kepler-40; French and Swiss astronomers used the equivalent to one night of measurements on the SOPHIE échelle spectrograph to collect all the data needed to show that a planet was producing the periodic dimming of Kepler-40. The planet, Kepler-40b, is twice the mass of Jupiter and slightly larger than it in size, making it as dense as Neptune. The planet is also nearly thirteen times hotter than Jupiter and orbits five times closer to its star than Mercury is from the Sun.
results.rationale: Kepler-40b can be considered a planet based on the provided definition. Firstly, it is in orbit around a star, Kepler-40, similar to how planets orbit the Sun. Secondly, it has sufficient mass, being twice the mass of Jupiter, which allows it to overcome rigid body forces and assume a nearly round shape, satisfying the hydrostatic equilibrium condition. Lastly, while it is not explicitly stated that Kepler-40b has cleared its orbit, the fact that it is the only planet mentioned in its system suggests that it likely has cleared its neighbourhood around its orbit. Therefore, Kepler-40b meets all the criteria in the definition to be classified as a planet.

To classify HD 34445 g as a planet, we would need information confirming that it orbits around the star (the Sun in this system), has sufficient mass to maintain a nearly round shape due to its self-gravity, and has cleared its orbit's neighbourhood. Without this information, we cannot confirm that HD 34445 g is a planet based on the provided definition.

Kepler-1647b (sometimes named Kepler-1647(AB)-b to distinguish it from the secondary component)  is a circumbinary exoplanet that orbits the binary star system Kepler-1647, 3,700 light-years (1,100 pc) from Earth in the constellation Cygnus. It was announced on June 13, 2016, in San Diego at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society. It was detected using the transit method, when it caused the dimming of the primary star, and then again of the secondary star blended with the primary star eclipse.
The first transit of the planet was identified in 2012, but at the time the single event was not enough to rule out contamination, or confirm it as a planet. It was discovered by the analysis of the Kepler light-curve, which showed the planet in transit.
results.rationale: The description of Kepler-1647b indicates that it is a celestial body that orbits a binary star system, which is similar to orbiting the Sun as stated in the definition of a planet. It is also mentioned that it was detected using the transit method, which implies that it has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit. Although the description does not explicitly state that Kepler-1647b has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, it is reasonable to infer this from the fact that it was identified as a planet. Therefore, based on the provided definition, Kepler-1647b can be considered a planet.

results.name: Nu2 Lupi b
results.description: Nu2 Lupi (ν2 Lupi) is a 6th magnitude G-type main-sequence star located approximately 48 light-years away in the constellation of Lupus. The physical properties of the star are similar to those of the Sun, though Nu2 Lupi is significantly older.
results.rationale: The provided description does not provide enough information to definitively assert that Nu2 Lupi b is a planet. Therefore, based solely on the provided information, we cannot assert that Nu2 Lupi b is a planet.

results.name: C/1957 P1 (Mrkos)
results.description: Comet Mrkos, formally known as C/1957 P1 (old style 1957d), was a non-periodic comet discovered in 1957 by Antonín Mrkos. It was one of  two bright comets that had their perihelion in 1957, the other being Comet Arend–Roland. Its peak magnitude was estimated to be around 1 and it has been characterised as a great comet.
results.rationale: The assertion that C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) is a planet cannot be supported based on the provided definition and information. The definition of a planet states that it must be in orbit around the Sun, have sufficient mass to assume a nearly round shape due to its self-gravity, and have cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit. The description of C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) identifies it as a non-periodic comet, not a planet. Comets are typically composed of ice, dust, and rock, and do not have the mass necessary to assume a round shape due to self-gravity. Furthermore, comets do not clear their orbit but rather, they leave a trail of debris. Therefore, C/1957 P1 (Mrkos) does not meet the criteria to be classified as a planet.

results.name: 6P/d'Arrest
results.description:
6P/d'Arrest (also known as d'Arrest's Comet or Comet d'Arrest) is a periodic Jupiter-family comet in the Solar System, orbiting between Mars and Jupiter. It passed 0.15124 AU (22,625,000 km; 14,059,000 mi) from the Earth on August 12, 1976. The most recent perihelion passage took place on September 17, 2021, when the comet had a solar elongation of 95 degrees at approximately apparent magnitude of 10.The comet last came to perihelion (closest approach to the Sun) on March 2, 2015, but it was in an unfavorable apparition as it had a solar elongation of less than 30 degrees from October 2014 until May 2015.In 1991, Andrea Carusi and Giovanni B. Valsecchi (Istituto Astrofisica Spaziale, Rome), and Ľubor Kresák and Margita Kresáková (Slovak Astronomical Institute, Bratislava) independently suggested this comet was the same as a comet observed by Philippe de La Hire in 1678.It was first observed by Heinrich Ludwig d'Arrest, in Leipzig, Germany, on 28th and 30 June 1851.The comet nucleus is estimated at about 3.2 km in diameter.6P/d was one of a trio of comets targeted by the ill-fated CONTOUR mission, an unmanned discovery program mission, that was launched but contact was lost soon after reaching orbit.
If it had been functional, the planned date for CONTOUR's study of d'Arrest would have been 2008, after visiting two other comets.Around 2007, 6P/d was one of nine comets examined for a comet sample return mission study. In the 2010s a comet surface sample return mission was selected as the New Frontiers Program finalist, but the recently studied comet 67P was chosen as the selected target.
results.rationale: Based on the provided definition, it is not possible to argue that 6P/d'Arrest is a planet. The definition of a planet states that it must be in orbit around the Sun, which 6P/d'Arrest is. However, the definition also states that a planet must have sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and it must have cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit. The description of 6P/d'Arrest does not provide information to confirm these two criteria. It is described as a comet, which typically do not meet the criteria for being classified as a planet. Therefore, based on the provided definition and description, it cannot be argued that 6P/d'Arrest is a planet.

results.name: 893 Leopoldina
results.description: 893 Leopoldina (prov. designation: A918 KD or 1918 DS) is a large and elongated background asteroid from the outer regions of the asteroid belt. It was discovered by German astronomer Max Wolf at the Heidelberg Observatory on 31 May 1918. The dark carbonaceous C-type asteroid has a rotation period of 14.1 hours and measures approximately 76 kilometers (47 miles) in diameter. It was named for Germany's national academy, the Academy of Sciences Leopoldina in Halle.
results.rationale:
Based on the provided definition, it is not possible to argue that 893 Leopoldina is a planet. The definition states that a planet is a celestial body that is in orbit around the Sun, has sufficient mass for its self-gravity to overcome rigid body forces so that it assumes a hydrostatic equilibrium (nearly round) shape, and has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit. 

The description of 893 Leopoldina only mentions that it is a large and elongated background asteroid from the outer regions of the asteroid belt. It does not provide information on whether it has sufficient mass to overcome rigid body forces and assume a nearly round shape, nor does it mention if it has cleared the neighbourhood around its orbit. Therefore, based on the provided information, it cannot be argued that 893 Leopoldina is a planet.
